page.title: 01Land Southwest of Sorbie
page.content: Much of this land is bog land, poorly drained and flooded much of the year. The land which is on higher ground is used for rough grassland for grazing of dairy cattle. The land to the Eastern side is of better quality and wheat is grown. The farms have characteristic grain silos. Wind pumps can be seen which drain the land by pumping out water. Many drainage dykes (Burns) have been built and enlarged, showing as straight lines on maps. The ground is hillocky and where grassed, contains much gorse and thistle bushes. Some cheviot (pure white with long upright ears) sheep and some suffolks (black headed compact sheep) are also seen grazing the poorer quality grassland, usually in between the unmanaged deciduous woodland.
